title: Core Definitions
content: We define largestPrimeFactor P(n) and smallestPrimeFactor p(n) using Finset operations and Nat.minFac, then axiomatize fBinom(n) = min_{1 < k ≤ n/2} gcd(n, C(n,k)). The axiomatization avoids sorry in the nonemptiness proof of the minimization range.
significance: These are the building blocks for stating all bounds and open questions about f(n).

title: Basic Sandwich Bounds
content: The function f(n) satisfies p(n) ≤ f(n) ≤ n/P(n) for composite n ≥ 2, where p(n) is the smallest prime factor and P(n) the largest. This follows from properties of binomial coefficients and Kummer's theorem on p-adic valuations.
significance: The sandwich p(n) ≤ f(n) ≤ n/P(n) frames all three open questions: when is the upper bound tight, can f be close to √n, and how fast does f grow?

title: Semiprime and n=30 Equalities
content: For semiprimes n = pq (p ≤ q both prime), f(pq) = p = n/P(n), achieving the upper bound. The example f(30) = 6 = 30/5 shows this also holds for some non-semiprimes (30 = 2·3·5).
significance: Semiprimes provide the simplest exact computation. The n=30 case shows the characterization problem (Question 1) is nontrivial beyond semiprimes.

title: Question 1: Characterization of f(n) = n/P(n)
content: Which composite n satisfy f(n) = n/P(n)? Known examples are semiprimes pq and n = 30. The placeholder axiom marks this as an open characterization problem.
significance: A full characterization would reveal when binomial coefficients are maximally divisible by n, connecting to the structure of prime factorizations.

title: Question 2: Infinitely Many n with f(n) > √n
content: f(p²) ≥ p = √(p²) shows Question 2 holds for prime squares. The open question is whether there are infinitely many composite n (not just prime squares) with f(n) > √n.
significance: A positive answer would show f(n) can be surprisingly large relative to n, far exceeding the smallest prime factor for infinitely many n.

title: Question 3: Upper Bound Conjecture
content: Is f(n) ≪_A n/(log n)^A for every fixed A > 0? This would mean f(n) is much smaller than n/P(n) for most composite n, since P(n) is typically around log n.
significance: This conjecture connects to the distribution of prime factors and would quantify how far f(n) is from its upper bound for typical composite numbers.
